title: 107_hr2480
content:
The "Conservation Investment Act of 2001" increases the maximum number of acres allowed in the Conservation Reserve Program to 40,000,000 by 2011. It also establishes the Grassland Reserve Program under the Food Security Act of 1985. The Secretary will establish a grassland reserve program through the Farm Service Agency to assist owners in restoring and conserving eligible natural grass or shrubland. The program will enroll a maximum of 3,000,000 acres, with specific acreage limits for restored and virgin grassland. Landowners can enroll a minimum of 100 contiguous acres west of the 90th meridian or 50 contiguous acres east of it through easements of 10, 15, or 20 years. The Secretary will establish a grassland reserve program through the Farm Service Agency to assist owners in restoring and conserving eligible natural grass or shrubland. The program will enroll a maximum of 3,000,000 acres, with specific acreage limits for restored and virgin grassland. Landowners can enroll a minimum of 100 contiguous acres west of the 90th meridian or 50 contiguous acres east of it through easements of 10, 15, or 20 years. The program allows for the inclusion of land that is natural grass or shrubland, historically dominated by such vegetation, or incidental to the described land if necessary for efficient administration. "SEC. 1238A. EASEMENTS AND AGREEMENTS." To enroll land in the program, the landowner must grant an easement to the Secretary, create a deed restriction, provide consent from relevant parties, show proof of title, comply with easement terms, retire cropland base, and allow easement termination in specific circumstances. The landowner must grant an easement to the Secretary allowing common grazing practices, haying, and construction of fire breaks and fences. The easement can be suspended or terminated during war, extreme drought, or famine, with payment adjustments as necessary. The Secretary can grant easements for common grazing practices, haying, and construction of fire breaks and fences. Easements prohibit certain agricultural activities that disturb the land surface and include additional provisions as needed. The Secretary establishes criteria to evaluate and rank easement applications. The Secretary establishes criteria for evaluating and ranking easement applications, emphasizing support for native grass and shrubland, grazing operations, and biodiversity. Restoration agreements for grasslands under easements are prescribed, outlining duties of landowners and the Secretary. Violations of easement terms may result in refunding payments received with interest, and periodic inspections are conducted by the Secretary. The Secretary conducts periodic inspections of land under easements to ensure compliance with terms and restoration agreements, allowing landowners to be present during inspections. "SEC. 1238B. DUTIES OF SECRETARY." The Secretary shall provide easement payments, Federal share of restoration, and technical assistance to landowners in exchange for granting an easement under this subchapter. Easement payments are based on the grazing value of the land, restoration costs are covered up to 90% for virgin grassland and 75% for restored grassland, and technical assistance is provided for executing easement documents and grassland restoration. The Commodity Credit Corporation will reimburse the Secretary for up to 10% of easement acquisition costs and restoration payments. If an owner is unable to receive payment, the Secretary will make the payment in a fair manner. Easement payments received will not affect other federal payments the owner is eligible for. SEC. 1238C. ADMINISTRATION. The Secretary may delegate the enforcement of easements to private organizations or State agencies if it promotes grassland conservation and the landowner agrees. Organizations must apply for approval and be competent in administering grassland easements. The Secretary may delegate easement enforcement to private organizations or State agencies for grassland conservation. If an organization terminates an easement, the landowner must reassign it to another approved organization or the Secretary. Regulations for this subchapter must be issued within 180 days of enactment. Funding is amended to include subchapters C and D. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN MAXIMUM NUMBER OF ACRES AUTHORIZED TO BE ENROLLED IN THE WETLANDS RESERVE PROGRAM. The total number of acres enrolled in the wetlands reserve program is increased annually from 1,225,000 acres in 2002 to 2,575,000 acres in 2011.

SEC. 5. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY INCENTIVES PROGRAM. SEC. 5. ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY INCENTIVES PROGRAM. Funding for the program is increased to $1.4 billion for fiscal year 2002 and $1.2 billion for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2011. Contract terms are amended to allow for 1 to 10-year contracts. Payment limitations are repealed. SEC. 7. FUNDING OF FARMLAND PROTECTION PROGRAM. The Secretary will use up to $50,000,000 annually from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds for fiscal years 2002 through 2011. SEC. 8. SMALL WATERSHED REHABILITATION AMENDMENTS OF 2000. $60,000,000 allocated for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2011. SEC. 9. EFFECTIVE DATE. Amendments take effect on October 1, 2001.
